150625196.review:
I guess this is alright if you are really into idle games. It's not my thing tho and as such I cannot legitimately recommend it to anyone. At least it was free. If Steam had the option, I would give a "neutral" rating.

I'll keep my review brief (EDIT: haha, yeah, right), and I am only describing the main game, not any of the DLCs.

Pros:
- It's free. You can try it without wasting money, although I will not take responsibility for you wasting your time / life.
- You can unlock most things in the game without buying pixels with real money (aside from the DLC contents, of course). It will take you a while, however. I am not sure there are enough pink gems from achievement progress in order to unlock all phone flings as well as speed up money generation / hobby progress, either.
- It is an idle game, meant for you to touch briefly, then close and check back some time later. It "stores" (or rather, calculates) your progress while the game is closed, giving you all idle profits (for up to 7 days) when you come back.
- It is not terribly hard to modify your save file once you find it, although you are going to have to use the atob() and btoa() JavaScript functions (or similar alternatives) to convert the names and values of the saved properties to and from the "encoded" Base64 strings. This makes it easy to get your speedup multiplier to the max (2048) and give yourself enough pink gems to speed up levelling and money to bearable levels while also unlocking all phone flings.
- Bearverly has such a charming, melodic voice and a wonderful sense of humour.
- On a more serious note, I am genuinely enjoying some of the pickup lines here.

Cons:
- Things still are going to take forever - one of the achievements expects you to play for an entire year (which includes the "stored" time), so go figure.
- There is a mechanic that allows you to reset all your gameplay progress (besides phone flings and achievements) which increases an internal speed-up multiplier. Every time you double that multiplier by resetting, you can get back to where it was in a fraction of the time it took you to get there before. Roughly speaking, of course. However, it caps out at 2048x speed... which is [b][i]still painfully slow[/i][/b] after the initial few minutes, even if you use pink gams to speed things up on top of it. Again, it is an idle game that expects you to not play thoroughly for an extended period of time, but rather spread your attention thin and only check in every now and then. This concept works great with a mobile game, but I am not a fan on PC.
- The achievements only work ingame, none of them have unlocked for me in Steam. This might be because I prevent access to whatever login IP the game tries to connect to upon startup. That really should not be an issue though, right? Because other games have not attempted to connect to anything and yet unlocked achievements.

150510537.review:
What I Like:

The game is addictive: The game has a structure that draws me in. The simple gameplay and the process of completing the various missions makes it an enjoyable way to spend my time.

Visuals and Animations: The game has colorful and attractive graphics. The character designs and animations enrich the atmosphere of the game and make for a more enjoyable experience.

Characters with Different Personalities: The different characters in the game offer a unique experience, each with their own story and interests. This allows me to have different experiences when interacting with the characters.

Dislikes:

Repetitive Gameplay: The game can get repetitive as it progresses. Continuously doing similar missions can get boring at times and cause the game to become monotonous.

Slow Progression: Some missions can take a while to complete, resulting in slow progression. Especially in the later levels, it can take a lot of effort to progress.

Reward Imbalance: The rewards I receive for my time and effort are sometimes unsatisfying. A more balanced reward system could increase the motivation of the game.

While this game is a fun experience for me, the repetitive nature and slow progression can sometimes detract from my enjoyment. However, I can say that the different characters and colorful visuals keep me engrossed.

150090705.review:
This review will focus on the question "Should I spend money on this free waifu idle clicker?" I will say the following statement: [b]You HAVE to purchase the $5 Catara bundle for this idle clicker to resemble a game[/b].  So here is the review with the $5 requirement in mind.

The gameplay is a simple idle game. You click on a girl to get hearts. You are also managing hobbies and jobs. The limitation at firstnis your time blocks which prevents you from having multiple jobs and hobbies at the same time. then as you advance through the game, you will unlock more time blocks, and the barrier to advance becomes waiting for your hobbies or jobs to train. The girls have different requirement, some of which include buying gifts, and going on a specified amount of dates.
 
Prestige (soft resetting the game) will reduce these times waiting for skills to train down, with you having to level up the girls again and again. Eventually you will cap out prestige and then you will have to use time boost, which are purchased with diamonds. Diamonds are also used to unlock a large portion of the "extra" girls. You earn diamonds in game as you unlock girls, and at a rate of 1 diamond (sometimes 3) a day. So theoretically you can unlock nearly all of the game but that would take literal years. It is up to you if you wanna just buy the diamonds with real money, but I don't recommend.

The requirement of the Catara $5 bundle is because Catara gives you the "Speed dating" ability. What this does is let you click a single button next to some of the required gift and dates the girls have, and you will insta fill them as long as you have the in-game cash. As you advance through the game, you will find the girls start with requiring "4 beach dates" and you will click into the date option, select the beach date, then click the redo button 3 more times. Or you will have to purchase 5 designer purses, by clicking the gift, then the next arrow untill you get to the bags, then buy a bag 5 times, buy or 5 bags if you have the full amount. 

Very quickly these numbers will jump to 30+ movies dates and hundreds of flowers. You will have to spend countless hours clicking through the date menu, and wrestling with purchasing 100 donuts 7 times, or just get the 1k donuts and over purchase 300. The Catara Speed date button removes all of this and lets you fast click these single clicks, and rapidly level up girls and re-prestige.

The game is actually quite fun with this repeatable pattern. You log in, quickly level up what you can, collect your daily diamond, check out some phone flings, and log out. The gameplay loop will eventually lead you to a wait thats proably too long, but I feel the $5 Catara bundle will give you more than $5 worth of entertainment. You turn your attentiont o a list of requirements and how you will best approach leveling up the skills and hobbies. The removal of the date and gift menu juggling actually makes it rather enjoyable. So I recommend paying $5. I personally have the $15 Darya bundle and a few of the smaller girl bundles. I find them fun and entertaining enough to warrant their price. 

I do not recommend buying diamond bundles. The game eventually will end with you waiting hours and hours for that ridiculous super end game, final unlocks. The diamond bundles speed you up to that process. The Functionality of Speed dating does too, but you at least enjoy it.

Crush Crush is a game that has captivated me for more than three years now so for me, It's not just a game, but has become a part of my life. I have experienced so many wonderful moments with this game, from meeting and flirting with a variety of beautiful anime girls, to unlocking amazing jobs and hobbies, to collecting stunning pinups and outfits. This game has everything I could ask for in a dating sim: humor, romance, fun, and a bear for some reason.

The game is very easy to play, but also very rewarding. You can progress even when you are not playing, thanks to the Time Blocks feature. You can also boost your progress with optional in-game purchases, but they are not necessary to enjoy the game. The game is very generous with its content, and it is constantly updated with new girls, events, and features.

The best part of the game is the girls themselves. They are all unique and charming, with different personalities, preferences, and stories. They are also fully voiced by talented actresses who bring them to life. You can interact with them in various ways, from giving them gifts and taking them on dates, to tickling them and making them blush. You can also unlock saucy pics of them when you reach Lover status, which are very well-drawn and captivating.

Crush Crush is one of the best games that I grew up with, and I still love it to this day. It is a game that makes me smile, laugh, and feel happy. I would recommend it to anyone who is looking for a fun and flirty game to kill some time and make you laugh out loud. Trust me, you won't regret it.

Fun little casual idler/clicker dating sim, I've spent a lot of time on this one on another site but decided to get it on Steam and send some actual money to the devs. Yes, it gets samey and repetitive... But that's part of the mechanics, much as grinding in any game. The basic game is roughly PG-13, even if you might not want to get caught playing it at work or school, and I've enjoyed unlocking the various women and learning to know them. I'm particularly glad that Sad Panda Studios has kept adding stuff to it beyond what I originally saw some years back, might need to consider tossing more money their way! Though first I'll focus on getting all of the free gems I can. =) Haven't played the NSFW version, but probably will eventually.  Also glad to see they've done other games, I'll have to take a look at those as well!

The regular version is free to play, so you can get a good taster of what it has to offer so you can decide if its for you (and your wallet). Save up those precious free diamonds for speed multipliers and don't forget that RESET is your friend for a quicker game! Just be careful NOT to do a FULL reset...

If there's ONE complaint that I have, its that I'd wish they'd have a Japanese audio track for the women... But as it is made by an English-speaking studio that probably doesn't have that big of a budget, perfectly understandable, and the English track is nice as far as I've heard the girls (up to Nina, Alpha and Pamu).

147597609.review:
If this wasn't built up as a hentai game I would say it's kind of worth a look, even if you don't like clickers.

But, big surprise, the actual nudity is behind a paywall. And judging from the reviews there, it's not even interesting.

Which is a shame, because credit where it's due: The writing and voice acting is actually successfully funny and at times likeable, and the building up of money and favor with the ladies is satisfying. The art looks like it came out of a high schooler's sudden surge of anime practice and finding their own style, but that's not necessarily a bad thing; it's distinctive and obviously successful enough at making these women sexy and interesting enough that the fact this doesn't have their full nude glory by default is a crippling con.

Thing is, knowing it's supposed to be for that purpose, and then having them put it behind a paywall - and the actual sexy stuff itself supposedly be mediocre at best anyway - it's just not worth it. If it's a clicker you want, there are plenty of SFW clickers here on Steam (Venture Capitalist, anyone?). If you want a game to play one-handed that actually gives you what it promises, there's Come Home by RJ Rhodes-  also free, by the way - or if you want a game that just has the courage to ask for money up front, "Space Rescue: Code Pink" or "Helping out the Hotties".

147392508.review: I've wasted far too many hours on a free-to-wait game that also pressures you to buy premium currency so you wouldn't miss out on a new character under a time limit. Why is this placed in the game, when at anytime the developers could've just sell another new DLC pack inside their Steam store page? The extra DLC could have had a collection of brand new/existing characters to date in this clicker game. Some of the characters cost little premium currency as much as 4 USD individually or more, while some of the characters cost 15 USD each, and the choice of costume are a dollar or more depending on the characters. Whats even worse, is that most of them have to be bought through their premium currency, and the in-game store purposefully over charges you a fixed amount that wont be matched exactly to the cost of the characters or costumes you want. This could've been easier if the game charges you exactly the cost of the costumes and characters directly, with no issue. As for the boosts/perks, that could've easily been earned within the game itself than through premium currency. As for many of the characters in CrushCrush, they are usually one-note personalities while only some of them feel mildly charming, and of course a good amount of them are obvious parodies of actual IP characters from many shows, cartoons, anime, and video games, etc. (Even Ayano from Yandere Simulator is in this game, so I'm not sure if she will be staying in the game or not.) No one is immune to micro transactions in a "free game" and I especially am not immune to it either regrettably. Also just to let everyone to know, I have wasted 150.50 USD On this game! Unless the developers add character group packs in the store itself just to make it easier to directly buy, this clicker game is definitely not worth it.

145965583.review:
Just your typical casual, no-stakes, idle game that you log on every now and then to do dailies and go through the "story". I did not have the DLC btw. 

Pros: 
- casual and low-stakes
- idling time is very forgiven and there really isn't a pressure to log on, even if you miss the dailies because they simply repeat every month. 
- the LTE event is the most serious the game will ever get and is actually very easy once you know the strategy. 
- ui and settings are very dumb-people friendly, though I wish there was an option to set keybinds to make progress easier and/or faster rather than just clicking everything. 
- artwork and character design is really cool, spanning multiple different genres of character design. 
- in-game achievements are in the hundreds and I'm glad they are not all part of Steam achievements. I also liked how these in-game achievements provide some sort of reward and wasn't just for naught. 

Cons:

- dialogue and voice acting is quite unremarkable ngl......

144879867.review:
I'm sure my parents are very proud I spent 200+ hours on a pornographic clicker game. This is the exact thing I was brought into this world to experience. The joy of clicking a bunch of buttons repeatedly to get virtual girls to like me. It's kind of like texting, which btw is also in this game now. 

Jokes aside, this game has been on Steam for a while, and aside from the problem of being a clicker game, it does have a few issues regarding the first few girls generally being very boring compared to the later ones and the event or phone fling girls. It's also designed to take a very long time to play, as in you are expected to reset your progress in exchange for a "boost" to the timers, and repeat that over and over and over again until eventually you reach a point where it doesn't take several weeks to finish maxing out affection for some of the later girls. 

There's also some paywalled stuff, as expected of a "free" game, and it's of inconsistent quality. The porn patch is an obvious buy, but there's also a cash shop which includes some unlockable girls like Darya and the Monster Girls (who don't even have voice acting).

Overall it's a clicker, with all the problems that entails. You mindlessly click buttons repeatedly, let timers complete, buy gifts and go on dates to finish each girl's mostly self contained romance. There is a "story" to the game, but it's barely there and it's completely ignored for all the event and paywalled girls. The "phone fling" girls are much better written because there's a long string of texts going back and forth between you and them often detailing a storyline that leads to them being unlocked in the game proper. But it's still based on nothing more than an idle timer and your ability to click one button when the timer runs out.

For a free porn game, it's good. But keep in mind it is still at the end of the day, a clicker game.

A Whimsical and Addictive Clicker Game with a Few Drawbacks

Crush Crush is an enchanting and highly addictive clicker game that has captured the hearts of players with its charming characters and engaging gameplay. Developed by Sad Panda Studios, this casual dating simulator introduces players to a delightful world filled with romance, humor, and quirky personalities. Although Crush Crush offers a delightful experience, there are a few minor drawbacks that deserve a mention. Let's dive into the positive aspects while keeping an eye on its cons.

Pros:

Lovable Characters: Crush Crush's characters are endearing and relatable, each with their unique personalities and backstories. The game allows players to interact with a diverse cast of individuals, making the dating experience feel personal and enjoyable.

Casual Gameplay: The clicker mechanics in Crush Crush are simple and accessible, making it a perfect choice for players seeking a relaxing and casual gaming experience. The game doesn't demand intense strategy, allowing players to enjoy it at their own pace.

Quirky Humor: Crush Crush is packed with witty dialogue and playful humor that keeps players entertained throughout their dating adventures. The game strikes a perfect balance between lightheartedness and sincerity, making it a joy to engage with.

Free-to-Play Friendly: The game is very free-to-play friendly, offering a generous amount of in-game currency and opportunities to progress without the need for real money purchases. This approach ensures that players can fully enjoy the game without feeling pressured to spend.

Cons:

Time-locked Progression: Crush Crush utilizes a time-locked progression system, which might frustrate players who prefer a more linear and faster-paced experience. Waiting for characters to become available or for time gates to pass can interrupt the flow of gameplay.

Repetitive Gameplay: While the initial stages are engaging, the game can become slightly repetitive in the later stages. The core mechanics stay relatively consistent throughout, which may reduce some of the excitement for long-term players.

Limited Depth: Crush Crush is designed as a light-hearted dating simulator, and as such, it lacks the depth and complexity found in more elaborate games of the same genre. Players seeking a more immersive dating experience might find it lacking in depth.

In conclusion, Crush Crush is a delightful and addictive clicker game that charms players with its lovable characters and whimsical humor. Its casual gameplay and free-to-play approach make it accessible to a wide audience, while its witty writing keeps players engaged. Although the time-locked progression and occasional repetitive gameplay might be drawbacks for some players, Crush Crush remains a charming and enjoyable experience overall. Whether you're a fan of dating sims or simply looking for a fun and lighthearted game to play, Crush Crush is sure to win you over with its adorable characters and endearing charm.

Rating: ★★★★☆ (4/5 stars)

Crush Crush is a delightful free-to-play dating simulation game developed by Sad Panda Studios. Set in a vibrant world filled with quirky characters, Crush Crush delivers a charming mix of romance, time management, and clicker mechanics that will keep players captivated for hours.

The first thing that strikes players about Crush Crush is its colorful and whimsical art style. The game's vibrant visuals, charming character designs, and appealing animations create an endearing atmosphere that perfectly complements the dating simulation theme. Each character is uniquely crafted with distinct personalities, making them feel like real individuals with whom you can develop genuine connections.

The gameplay revolves around pursuing romantic interests, and the core mechanics are surprisingly addictive. Players must manage their time efficiently to balance work, hobbies, and social interactions with various characters. As you progress, you'll unlock new jobs, hobbies, and date locations, adding depth to the gameplay and keeping things fresh.

The dating aspect itself is engaging, as you'll embark on a journey to win the affection of different characters. Each character comes with a unique storyline, presenting players with enjoyable narratives to explore. Building relationships requires genuine effort, and as you advance, the characters become more endearing, encouraging you to invest emotionally in their well-being.

An interesting feature of Crush Crush is the incremental progress system. The game employs a clicker-like mechanic that rewards players for regular engagement. Upgrading skills, buying gifts, and enhancing the characters' affection levels all contribute to the sense of achievement and progression.

Moreover, Crush Crush adopts a fair free-to-play model, where purchasing in-game currency is optional, and most content can be accessed without spending real money. While some items may require patience to acquire through gameplay, it never feels overly restrictive or pay-to-win, making it accessible to a wide range of players.

Despite its charming and addictive qualities, Crush Crush does have a minor drawback. The game may feel somewhat repetitive after extended play sessions, especially during the initial stages when waiting times for events and dates are longer. However, the game's casual nature makes it perfect for short, fun bursts of play rather than extended sessions.

In conclusion, Crush Crush is a delightful and engaging dating simulation game that offers an enjoyable mix of romance and time management mechanics. Its whimsical art style, quirky characters, and clicker elements create a captivating experience that appeals to players of various interests. While some may find it repetitive over time, the game's accessible free-to-play model and lovable cast of characters make it a worthwhile experience for anyone looking to embark on a heartwarming love adventure.

Having been introduced to the male counterpart, Blush Blush, first, it was clear to me which game came out first. However, that doesn't mean this game is worse than Blush Blush. I've got to admit, despite having the same Pay To Play and week-long time gaps to achieve the smallest things, the game does feel slightly less tedious than Blush Blush. I feel like the slow progress is more (but only slightly more) achievable. I've made it to the same point of the game more than once, but I've noticed a lot more progression beyond the same point than I did for Blush Blush
I would like to compliment the art style, as it is nicely detailed and sometimes even super pretty, but Marshmallow (aka us) is difficult to make look good, and often looks pretty bad in most sprites of them. I also don't know if it's just me, but the style feels very inconsistent
The characters are attractive, but are usually one-note personalities and character stereotypes. Progressing to the next levels don't feel as gratifying as they could be if the characters were just a little more developed
I do like a lot of the dialogue and stories. The stories tend to roll with the game's title, and I like the consistency of the "CRUSHED" joke, as it suits the game a lot. Not to mention that I've found myself smiling at how charming and comedic the game can be at times, which is more than I can say for Blush Blush
I also very much enjoy Limited Time Events. As grindy as they are, it feels like I'm actually playing the game and not just waiting weeks for something to go up by two levels. I also get to unlock free rewards and a character if I play enough, as well as perks to help me beat the event, which feels pretty fun in my opinion
Though that can also be a problem for those who don't wish to log in to the game every few hours or so to check up on it, as can the concept of LTE's itself, because missing them usually puts characters behind an expensive paywall of a year's worth of building up diamonds, or a large chunk of real money, unless you're willing to wait however lng for the event to roll around again with the potentiality of it not even being worth the wait if you don't win
I will also say that a lot of the dialogue feels unnatural. Either the situation goes from 1 to 100 really fast, or some lines take you out of immersion, if any was established

As I said for the other one, if you're an impatient person, or just don't want to be sucked into an addicting Pay To Play, this game isn't for you. If you're after pretty girls (and a LOT of "boba" and derrière talk), this is perfect for you

As someone who's spent countless hours playing Crush Crush, I can confidently say that this game is an absolute blast! From the moment I started my journey through the world of romance, I was hooked, and there was no turning back.

What struck me right away was the game's charming art style. The adorable characters, each with their unique personalities, instantly won me over. From the energetic and quirky Bearverly to the stoic and mysterious Q-Piddy, I found myself genuinely invested in their stories. The character designs are so cute and well-crafted that it's impossible not to fall in love with them!

The gameplay mechanics are where Crush Crush truly shines. Balancing my time between managing my job, hobbies, and dates added an exciting challenge to the dating simulation genre. It felt like a real-life juggling act, making decisions on who to focus my attention on while keeping an eye on the clock. I'd often find myself strategizing to optimize my time and energy to get the most out of every in-game day.

The game's progression system is rewarding and keeps you coming back for more. As you level up your relationships with the characters, you unlock new outfits, gifts, and special interactions. The sense of accomplishment when winning the affection of a character you've been pursuing is incredibly satisfying!

What also keeps me glued to Crush Crush is the constant updates and events. The developers at Sad Panda Studios regularly add new characters, stories, and events, ensuring there's always something fresh to explore. This level of commitment from the developers shows how much they care about their player community.

Crush Crush doesn't take itself too seriously, and that's part of what makes it so fun! The game is filled with humor and clever references, providing plenty of laugh-out-loud moments. It's a refreshing break from the intensity of other games and creates a laid-back and enjoyable atmosphere.

The in-game monetization is well-handled, with microtransactions being optional and not overly intrusive. While some items can be purchased, it's entirely possible to progress and enjoy the game without spending a dime.

In conclusion, Crush Crush is a gem of a dating simulation game that has captured my heart. The adorable characters, addictive gameplay, and constant updates make it a delight to play. Whether you're a fan of dating sims or just looking for a charming and fun experience, Crush Crush is sure to steal your heart!

heres a recipe for pancakes

100g plain flour
2 large eggs
300ml milk
1 tbsp sunflower or vegetable oil, plus a little extra for frying
lemon wedges to serve (optional)
caster sugar to serve (optional)

1. Sift the dry ingredients together.
2. Make a well, then add the wet ingredients. Stir to combine.
3. Scoop the batter onto a hot griddle or pan.
4. Cook for two to three minutes, then flip.
5. Continue cooking until brown on both sides.

STEP 1
Put 100g plain flour, 2 large eggs, 300ml milk, 1 tbsp sunflower or vegetable oil and a pinch of salt into a bowl or large jug, then whisk to a smooth batter.

STEP 2
Set aside for 30 mins to rest if you have time, or start cooking straight away.

STEP 3
Set a medium frying pan or crêpe pan over a medium heat and carefully wipe it with some oiled kitchen paper.

STEP 4
When hot, cook your pancakes for 1 min on each side until golden, keeping them warm in a low oven as you go.

STEP 5
Serve with lemon wedges and caster sugar, or your favourite filling. Once cold, you can layer the pancakes between baking parchment, then wrap in cling film and freeze for up to 2 months.

140759097.review:
It's an addictive game, sure. 

But it is NOT friendly to new users, at all. Either you're there every day for each event, or you can pay through the nose in diamonds. Each new character is 200 diamonds- that's $20 of diamonds, or about a half a year of your life spent collecting diamonds. So, lets say for example, you're a big fan of Nova. But you joined/re-joined the game not during that two-week span. Sorry, you can only really unlock her from behind a pay wall. 

And there will be no events, mini-games, anything like that- no way to earn it. Just gotta save up your Diamonds. But, since you will surely miss check-in days here and there, you will be bleeding Diamonds as you go. 

---

As for the "gameplay", the fun quickly fades away. It's got a Cookie Clicker-type casual energy, building your way up to becoming "lovers" with each girl...only to start from scratch, and do it all again, but a little bit faster. I'd lost all of my progress after doing a soft reset on my computer and not thinking to back things up - except for the outfits I got in old events, oddly enough. 

The mechanics are noticeably less friendly than the new-er male edition, Blush Blush. It could really use to get some visual improvements, to bring some fresh life into older characters.

The Phone Flings are probably the best part. Sure, you have about as much agency over what happens as in a Telltale Game, but at least it feels like you're actually interacting with the characters. And the fact that they tie together characters being cousins, siblings, or otherwise knowing each other between games- it's a very appreciated detail. 

But alas, if you should happen to bond with one of those characters, you are stuck behind that pay wall again. I understand micro-transactions, even if I'm not a fan...but imagine spending $100 to get five new girls who now hate you, that you have to veeeeerry slowly start to bond with. Then reset. Then bond a little further. Then reset.


It's addictive, but it's torture. I got into it because of the Game Grumps/Markiplier, but boy, do I ever wish I didn't. I would have liked to throw a few dollars into it at some point if I actually enjoyed it...but I don't.

It can take about an hour to do all the daily adjustments, and you're gonna want to check in at least twice a day. At some points, the repetition and music would cause me to take an impromptu nap, just because of the repetition. 

---

So until they stop punishing people who haven't been around since day one, I cannot possibly recommend this game.

Attention ! Bien entendu, ceci n'est qu'un jeu vidéo. La vraie vie, ça ne marche pas comme ça. Alors n'allez pas draguer un ours, ça va juste vous faire très mal !

Lorsque le jeu a vu le jour, j'ai eu beaucoup de mal avec le concept pour des raisons évidentes. Pour palier à ce problème, Sad Panda a eu le bon sens de faire deux choses : d'abord, ils ont fait Blush Blush qui est un reskin de Crush Crush dans l'autre sens (donc si le [spoiler]yaoi[/spoiler] vous intéresse, vous savez quel jeu il faut tester), ce qui permet de mettre tout le monde sur un pied d'égalité. Ensuite, la possibilité de choisir son genre, ce qui rend les deux jeux LGBT-friendly (Vous pouvez vérifier dans les cutscènes, que vous décidiez d'incarner un homme ou une femme, les scènes restent cohérentes). La seule chose dont vous aurez besoin, c'est d'apprécier les idle games et l'humour Gal-Gun-esque du jeu. Et franchement, ça reste mignon ! J'ai déjà joué à des jeux beaucoup plus dégradants dont je ne parlerai pas ici !

Concernant le gameplay, pour un idle game, c'est bien fichu, après, comme c'est un idle game, ne vous attendez pas à quelque chose de très complexe. Le jeu est fait pour y passer une heure de temps en temps et comme tous les idle games, vous regardez des chiffres devenir super super grands, ce qui permet d'obtenir d'autres nombres super super grands. Notons aussi que ce jeu doit presque tout à sa DA, très soignée et très agréable à l'oeil !

A l'attention de qui voudra l'entendre : je ne sais pas vraiment comment on drague, mais je peux affirmer que ce n'est pas comme ça, donc n'allez pas faire le pitre dans la vraie vie et pensez que vous pourrez vous racheter. :)

Fun idle game. Plenty of colourful and humorous dialogue, cute and funny character designs, daily log-ins can be completed in seconds. Every time I've had an issue, support has responded quickly. In the single instance they couldn't fix my issue, I was compensated with diamonds. If you like idle games and women, you'll probably like this game. If you want an idle game with more men, Blush Blush serves as a near identical counterpart that serves that need.

My only gripe is the limited time events. There are plenty of rewards that are relatively easy to get, but the limited characters tied to them are always the final reward. The events seem to require constant vigilance over the few days they're available, and you're not likely to complete them unless you buy the event bundle or convert your diamonds into event currency. They've never costed me much, but the point is every LTE so far has felt like I've had no choice but to pay to complete them. If you're not willing to spend money or use guides  (if LTE guides even exist) then I would recommend you avoid being overly concerned about completing them.

137389334.review:
This is the best clicker game I've played.
Likes:
     + Regularly added material (even some repeats so you can get girls/outfits/etc that you missed)
     + The writing, especially the in-jokes hinting at the inspiration for the girl
     + True clicker experience that can be played without spending much real money IF you take the time
     + Variety between the experiences with the girls, the phone flings, and the special events
     + Enjoyed the snark comments from/about Ayano and the other girls
     + When there are interactions/acknowledgement between the different girls. Wish there was more of that. 
     + Hilarious that the player is represented by a marshmallow looking guy/gal (under the stats main menu option you can select your avatar - though that doesn't appear to change the image in the scenes)

Dislikes (not show stoppers):
     - There are sometimes when you need to spend real money to advance or to get bonuses (understandably they have to make money from current players to add new content - though I can't think of a better way, at least they didn't go the subscription route)
     - Seems to take way too long to get to the final relationship stages with some of the girls
     - The images of the girls don't align well with their stats, especially their breast size. Would be nice to add heights to their stats.
    
 I do enjoy it, especially since I'm at the stage when it only takes a few minutes a day to keep up with it, outside of special events.

135715278.review:
If you like dating sims and idle clicker games, you'll enjoy this.

It has a nice balance of idleness in my opinion as it encourages daily login with events, but they're just 3 clicks and then if you want the extras another 2 clicks after an hour or so when they event extras finish their timer. When you're first starting out the extras may be annoying to claim, but once you've progressed far enough to have enough extra free time blocks they're super easy. To give a good balance whenever you have more time, you can actually progress through the story instead of just doing the dailies and spend more time in the game. 

Of course, it is possible to finish the game super quickly if you so desire, but then you'll just be bored and miss out on the fun you can have by progressing through this game slowly.

Even once you finish all the base content, they still add new text convos and characters to do on a semi-regular basis so it continues to be fun to progress slowly through those and makes it feel less like a waste of money to keep supporting the dev through whatever minor purchases you make. Unlike some games, the devs are not money hungry in this one. Most things can be gotten for free if you wait long enough.

134706415.review:
Crush Crush is a dating sim game that unfortunately falls short in several areas. Developed by Sad Panda Studios, the game features a basic premise where you date a series of anime-style girls by clicking on various options and progressing through different stages of the game. However, the game's overall execution leaves much to be desired.

One of the biggest issues with Crush Crush is its repetitive gameplay. The game quickly becomes tedious, as you're essentially doing the same thing over and over again. The interactions with the characters are shallow and lack depth, and there's little to no character development throughout the game. Additionally, the game's art style is uninspired and lacks creativity, making the characters feel flat and uninteresting.

Another issue with the game is its monetization strategy. While the game is free-to-play, it heavily relies on microtransactions to progress through the game at a reasonable pace. This can be frustrating for players who don't want to spend real money on the game, as progress can feel slow and tedious without it.

Overall, Crush Crush is a lackluster dating sim game that fails to deliver a compelling experience for players. Its repetitive gameplay, shallow characters, and reliance on microtransactions make it a game that's difficult to recommend.

TL;DR: Crush Crush is a dating sim game that falls short in several areas, including repetitive gameplay, shallow characters, and heavy reliance on microtransactions. It's a game that's difficult to recommend to players looking for a compelling dating sim experience.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

134347758.review:
Jesus. I’m not sure where to start with this game. I think I’ll start with the bottom line: I really hated this one.

I know, “hate” is a strong word - that's why I used it. For starters, the gameplay is godawful. How much do you like navigating menus? Would you like a game that is nothing but repetitive menus? Then this game is for you. For everyone else who doesn’t suffer from debilitating head trauma, stay away from this one.

You reach a dead-end with all of the different characters where the relationship can’t develop any farther. That makes sense and it's not too bad, since there are loads and loads of different characters. However, to unlock them, the player is required to make huge leaps in productivity. To do this, the player needs to restart the game over and over again, making only baby steps in productivity as they do. This leads to completing objectives (that is, navigating the same menus) for the same few characters over and over again in an effort to unlock someone new. It’s not fun.

As far as monetization goes, this one seems kind of predatory. There are a lot of characters that can only be unlocked by buying them. This isn’t bad in itself – the bad part is knowing that paying (too much) money to unlock them will to lead to more frustration and tedium. Oh, and don’t bother with buying the 18+ DLC: this is some of the worst art I've seen in an AO game and when it isn't laughable, it's fucking boring. On top of that, it unlocks one scene per character that the player sees at the very end of all the menuing they have to do to fill the character’s affection meter.

I'm tired and I don't feel like opening the game to see what other things suck about it. Just trust me: even though it's free, it's not worth the price of admission.

133853180.review:
Ingredientes
Para el relleno (boloñesa de carne): 500 g. de carne (una mezcla de cerdo y ternera)
2 pimientos rojos
2 zanahorias
2 dientes de ajo
150 g. de bacon o panceta
2 cebollas grandes
250 g. de tomate natural (1 vaso aproximadamente)
250 ml de vino blanco (200 ml. aproximadamente)
100 ml. de aceite de oliva virgen extra
1 cucharita colmada de orégano seco (o hierbas provenzales)
Sal y pimienta negra recién molida (al gusto de cada casa)
Para la lasaña:
12 láminas de lasaña o lasagna Garofalo
Para hacer la bechamel: (para un litro más o menos, la suficiente para la lasaña): 125 g de harina de trigo de todo uso
125 g de mantequilla
1 litro de leche entera
Una pizca de nuez moscada (unos 4 g.)
Sal y pimienta negra recién molida (al gusto de cada casa)
Para finalizar y gratinar la lasaña: 100-120 g. de queso rallado Grana Padano (o mezcla con vuestro queso preferido para gratinar)

Preparación de la lasaña de carne
Calentamos una cazuela grande de agua, la más ancha de casa. Cuando empiece a hervir echamos 2 puñados generosos de sal.
Introducimos las láminas de lasaña una a una sin que se toquen (para que no se peguen entre ellas). Ahora podemos encontrar infinidad de tipos de lasaña donde no hace hidratarla como se hacía antes. En casa muchas veces para ahorrar tiempo empleo las que se hidratan con la bechamel y el jugo que suelta la salsa al hornear.
Si lo hacéis de la manera tradicional tenemos que remover con una cuchara de madera y en unos 10 minutos sacamos las láminas. Las estiramos encima de unas hojas de papel absorbente de cocina. Aunque os parezca que no están, acabarán haciéndose en el horno.
El siguiente paso será lavar muy bien todas las verduras que vamos a emplear en el relleno. En la receta os aconsejo el relleno de la clásica salsa boloñesa, zanahorias, ajo, pimientos y cebolla.

Cómo hacer el relleno de lasaña de carne
Las verduras las cortamos en trocitos pequeños para que se junten bien en la salsa. Las zanahorias las cortamos lo más fino posible. Os recomiendo laminarlas con el pelador de las patatas porque a la hora de pocharlas si las tiras son gruesas no se hacen. Reservamos todo en un bol.
En otra cazuela echamos aceite de oliva virgen extra. Empezamos introduciendo pochando la cebolla y el ajo, cuando esté doradita, añadimos el resto de ingredientes.
Sofreímos todo a temperatura media durante unos 15 minutos y esperamos por la carne. Salpimentamos la carne al gusto y la echamos a la cazuela con la verdura. Dejamos que se pase durante 5 minutos y cuando veamos que va cambiando de color introducimos el bacon o panceta en trozos muy pequeños. Vertemos un vaso de vino blanco y esperamos a que reduzca (otros 5 minutos a fuego medio).
Añadimos un vaso de tomate natural, echamos la cucharadita de orégano y rectificamos de sal y pimienta si hiciese falta (probad la salsa para ver si está a vuestro gusto). Removemos la carne con las verduras y retiramos del fuego, dejamos enfriar un poco.
Precalentamos el horno a 200º C durante 15 minutos, lo justo para hacer el resto de la lasaña.

Preparación de la salsa bechamel y final de la receta
Mientras reposa la salsa vamos a preparar la bechamel, la podemos preparar más cremosa o más consistente dependiendo de las medidas. En el blog tenéis la receta de esta crema con todo lujo de detalles.
Para montar la lasaña la cosa es muy sencilla. Ponemos en el fondo de la fuente unas cucharadas de la bechamel. Encima las láminas, una capa de la mezcla con la carne en cada lámina, otra vez la bechamel y así hasta tener 3 pisos.
Se pueden hacer las capas de lasaña que quieras, bueno las que te permita la fuente. Finalmente rematamos con una capa generosa de bechamel. Y para aquellos que le guste el queso, rallamos aquel que más os guste, que sea especial para gratinar. Os recomiendo un queso curadito Grana Padano.
Horneamos en la bandeja del medio durante 15 minutos a 180º C y durante 3-5 minutos en la parte superior con el gratinador puesto para que se dore. Lista para comer, no hace falta reposo, del horno a la mesa.
Esta receta además de ser económica es una receta saludable, llena de proteínas e hidratos. Yo la presento siempre como plato único, espero que os guste.

133753687.review:
I’ve been dealing with crush crush for about 18 months now, and I’ve finally finished the game. 

I don’t think I can recommend this game to someone who’s trying to play for free, for one main glaring reason; the endgame is completely empty. Early game has reasons to log in. Things are progressing such that opening the game multiple times a day makes sense. Check on your money, affection, and hobbies. Progress through another relationship level, blow all your cash on gifts, get your login rewards, and close out for the night. You’re rewarded heavily for concurrent logins, and playing for at least an hour, getting new characters and diamonds most days that you do. There are some days that you’ll get a timeblock instead, or three diamonds. It averages out to one diamond per day.

Every time you advance a girl’s relationship level for the first time, you get a diamond. And if you max out a girl and complete all their requirements, you get 3. So each girl is good for about 11 diamonds, and there’s a lot of girls. 

So what do you spend diamonds on? There’s a lot of options and incentives to spend diamonds, but only one optimal choice, speed boosts. The max multiplier is x8192, and you will need all of it. Additionally, you’re going to want to spend 10 diamonds on the Astronaut job to make x5 the cash. The other jobs can help, but fractionally.

The speed boosts aren’t going to feel really needed until around hobby level 25-30. You’ll be resetting frequently and suddenly you’re going to hit a reset boost cap. Your reset cap is x2048 and it is NOT ENOUGH. Each hobby level takes about 50% longer to grind than the previous, and you need 75 in all hobbies to beat the game. 

So if the grind starts to get real around hobby level 30, and each level is 50% longer than the last, how on earth do you even get to 75? You don’t. Without speed boosts to compliment the reset cap, we are talking MONTHS. Multiple months. And it’s always getting worse.

Now you’re starting to understand why I’ve been playing for so long. These values (multiple months) were observed when I already had several speed boosts. I played through most of the game at x2048 Max reset boost, with x512 additional speed boost. 512 isn’t much compared to 8192, it’s only 1/16th of the max, so why did I stall there for so long? Let’s talk diamonds.

So how many diamonds do you need to get to beat this game (Max out your speed boost of x8192)? The options on the table are 40 diamonds for x2, 100 for x8, and 180 for x64. 180 diamonds is the most efficient pickup, so 400 diamonds for two x64 purchases and then a final x2 to finish it off. Build that x2 earlier on, because it’s going to be brutal to even unlock the girls needed to get these diamonds without it. For each time you have to increment your x64 into two purchases of x8, you waste 20 diamonds. So to be generous, the most you spend is 440 diamonds, which is 4 x8 purchases and that single x2 purchase.

The issue here is that, provided you can get access to everyone, and finish them (you cannot), there are only 20 girls in the base game. Of those 20, I guarantee you can’t max out 5 of them without having invested heavily into speed boosts, so the number is more like 15. That’s 165 gems, with another 55 behind a very steep timecurve. So the base game is interested in getting you 220 of your 400-440 gems. And you also need at least 10 for astronaut, probably another 10 for wizard. 

So how do you get the other 220 gems to finish off the game? Log-ins and extra girls. In order to get an extra girl, you need to be aware of the event ahead of time, and then consecutively log in for two weeks in a row, without EVER missing a day. As soon as you miss ONE DAY, you will have to spend diamonds to get the girl, and the amount you spend is greater than the 11 you’d get. 

The other consistent option is log-ins that require you to leave the game running for 1 hour, and then remember and tab back into the game and hit the collect button. That’s fine though, you’re playing the game right?

No, you aren’t. We’re finally at the crux of the matter, why this review is negative. You are not playing the game. There’s nothing to play; nothing to do. The devs exceeded their own content with these time gates. 90% of the time I have in this game is from logging in, waiting an hour, clicking a button, and logging out. Let me set the scene: My hobbies still have 27 days left to go from 63 to 64. Every single girl is either maxed out, or waiting on a hobby level of 64/65. I’m saving all of my money to buy Renee a mystical slipper. My character’s phone is buzzing off the hook, I suppose I can read fluff while I wait, but that’s also time locked, so I can’t, and there’s no reward to going through the phone flings scenarios except for Peanut (who herself is an endgame girl)

I had a great time with this game early on. I was playing with a buddy and we’d keep each other accountable for logging in. We ended up having 4 extra girls (thus an extra 44 diamonds). Once we reached hobby level 35-40 and things really started to slow to a crawl. I’m checking in every other day, every week, etc. My friend stopped playing and we latched onto my account as our account, it was easier to slog through that way. My in-game activity dropped from running resets and unlocking girls, to checking in every week or so to see how much progress my hobbies had made. I went into excel to graph out how long it would take me to reach level 75 INCLUDING my speed boost of x512, assuming the 50% per level time increase. It was (IIRC) about 180 more days. And this was at hobby level 62-63. After spending 650+ hours dealing with this game, or forgetting it was on, I wanted to be done. I bought the last 140 gems I needed to reach x8192  for 7 bucks and cleared the game out in the last three/four weeks. Those are diamonds I could have earned 1 day at a time, I didn’t play optimally for sure. After being able to get through the rest of the content, I now have 47 diamonds, so like I said, a lot of them are gated behind extreme endgame stuff. Even now though, my progress has been piecemeal, even running at the game’s max aggregate speed.

I have a fundamental problem with diamonds and how they’re used. The girls all cost 200 diamonds at baseline, which is (during this sale) around 15 bucks. If you’ve been following along, that number should be insane to you. 200 diamonds is 200 DAYS of loggins that we cannot afford to spend on a girl who does nothing for our progress and just gives 11 diamonds back. Your only way of seeing the content the devs made is through a two week commitment that is frankly very easy to forget to do, and designed to make you fail. Don’t think for a second I don’t see all the ways to misuse diamonds in this game. Timeskips, money skips, outfits, phone flings, the list goes on. These are intentional distractions from progress. Why does this bother me? Because to most people looking to play the game, it’s not immediately apparent that there’s only one avenue they can be spending diamonds on to actually play the game.

In summary: Is the game fun? For a time. If you want to play this game to completion, accept that you need to spend a bit of money for diamonds. I’d also suggest buying either Suzu or Charlotte, as they give access to a new job that seems to resolve most money concerns. To be clear, I think it’s a waste to just buy a x8192 speed boost at the start of the game, you’d blow through the best part of the game and nothing would have any value. It’s best to slowly aggregate speed boost normally, and then when you feel the halt of content, go ahead and boost up, accepting that you were planning to spend some anyway. So my recommendation is to plan to spend around 10 dollars over the course of the game. If that doesn’t sound like something you’d like to do, then don’t try it.

131967786.review:
I picked it up forever ago and never played. I have a resolution this year to burn through more of my Steam library (damned Steam sales).

This game is very interesting. The mechanics of the game are very simple, and it's a no-brainer to pick up on what it takes to achieve the goals as the player.

However, unless you "time travel" doing much of anything takes literal days and weeks of elapsed real-world time after not too long. Not terrible for an idle game, I suppose. At least they didn't turn anything into required micro-transactions.

Although I must admit, the dialogue in the game is good enough to get consistent laughs from me. Every character's storyline has some witty banter and player choices (with no real impact on outcomes).

I don't frequent NSFW games like explicit dating sims and the like, but I do enjoy experimenting with different kinds of games, their mechanics, and feature implementations.

Crush Crush turned out to be fun to play for the dialogue, but there's nothing too creative from a development perspective, and the challenge in the game is limited to normal idle game time-delay frustrations.

Weirdly enough, an idle game about becoming a mega-rich, talented, and charming blob didn't pull me at first. But, keeping with it, and actually exploring the game some more, I walk away with a really nice and sometimes really funny game where you get to know a bunch of strange characters with no real stakes. It's nice!

Now I have to say, there's references in this game that are hella obscure. In fact, I was also shocked to find there were some things in there that I don't even think you were to pick up on if you were just an American, as Sad Panda is a Canadian developer, and whoever wrote the dialogue wore that on their sleeve.

I spent money on Crush Crush because I felt like I was getting a lot out of the concept of being an inept marshmallow who falls in love with nearly anything that moves. I do feel like some of the jokes are on the aged side however, and is certainly a game of its time, but I don't fault it for that at all. It's cute, and 100%ing this was totally worth it.

I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

131191535.review:
I have to say that I am absolutely disgusted with this game. I spent at least $500 on it and all I got in return was a complete rip off. It's a complete waste of time and money. 

To begin, the gameplay is absolutely terrible. It's a clone of Cookie Clicker, so all you do is click on the screen and wait for bars to fill up. But the worst part is that it takes forever for the bars to fill. Even if you use gems to speed them up, it still takes MONTHS to finish the game. That's an absurd amount of time for a game like this and it's just not worth it. 

Then there's the adult content. It's true that there are some nice looking women in the game, but they are all overly endowed with big boobs. There's no subtlety or variety. It's just a bunch of giant boobs everywhere. To make matters worse, there's hardly any nudity. I mean, WASTED 23 MINUTES ON IT AND SAW ZERO TIDDIES. That's ridiculous for a game that's supposed to be about romance. I would have liked to see more nudity and hentai women scenes. Maybe then I wouldn't feel like my money was completely wasted. 

The writing is alright, but the delivery of the writing can be really tedious. The art is great and the voice acting is good, but it gets really repetitive. The animation also seems to be paywalled. All of this together makes the game really hard to enjoy. It's like the developers are trying to squeeze every last penny out of you.

Overall, I can't recommend this game at all. It's an evil cash grab game and it's not worth the time or money. Even if you have extra cash, don't buy this game. You'll just end up broke and disappointed. I would have liked to see more nudity and hentai women scenes. I would have liked to see more subtlety and variety in the artwork. Instead, all we got was a game that's slow and boring, and that's just not acceptable.

The storyline for many of the girls is kind of meh but a few of them have histories that really pull you in and make you feel connected to them emotionally. You honestly care about what happens to them.

The main game by itself is great but if you go the extra bit and get the uncensored dlc, it opens up so much more to you.

If you are willing to play the long game, you will love this one.
